title.narrative: 2.2 DISTRICT ESSENTIAL NUTRITION SYSTEM

description.narrative: By 2017, access to and utilization of essential nutrition services increased targeting newborn, infant, young children, adolescents, pregnant and lactating women, HIV affected children and women, and children and women with disabilities, which contributes to Community-Based Management Of Acute Malnutrition, Infant And Young Child Feeding, Micronutrients, Nutrition And Hiv, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2017, in selected areas (the most disadvantaged districts and municipalities), social sector systems are providing integrated, quality services to fulfil the survival, development, protection and participation rights of children, adolescents and women with equity in all contexts, including humanitarian situations

participating-org.narrative: EKDARA GA PA GA KA PA OFFICE

sector.narrative: Breastfeeding protection, promotion and support (including work on Code)
Care for children with severe acute malnutrition
Diet diversity in early childhood (children under 5), includes complementary feeding and MNPs
Immunization supply chain, including cold chain
Vitamin A supplementation in early childhood (children under 5)

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2017, access to and utilization of essential nutrition services increased targeting newborn, infant, young children, adolescents, pregnant and lactating women, HIV affected children and women, and children and women with disabilities

description.narrative: Sustained and maintained high standard coverage of essential and equitable nutrition services such as vitamin A (90%), iodised salt (>80%) and iron folic acid (80%); and management of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) amongst children under five years in line with SPHERE standard including children with disability and HIV. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:31/12/2017

title.narrative: % of pregnant and lactating women and adolescent girls (10-19 years) (age disaggregated) living in 15 priority districts covered with recommended dose of IFA and de-worming medicine

actual.value: 2018:90.9 per cent pregnant women (Out of 72,971) ever received iron folic acid tablet, of which 41.5 per cent took 180 + tablets. 51 per cent Adolescent girl age 10-19 years received weekly iron folic acid supplementation in 15 priority districts due to mobilization Health Workers and focal teachers.

title.narrative: % of infant, young children aged 6-59 months including children with disability and HIV affected in 15 priority districts fully covered with essential micronutrients services (Vit A, Iodized Salt and Multiple Micronutrient)

baseline.value: (average across 15 districts): Vit A (91 per cent), Iodized Salt (65 per cent), MNP Coverage (10 per cent in 2012 intervention districts with data = 42 per cent average, 2 intervention districts wit

title.narrative: Number of districts with operationalized IMAM programme including functional nutrition surveillance system

target.value: 2017:31 districts by 2017 with operationalized IMAM programme

actual.value: 2017:39 of the 42 targeted districts have a functional programme for Integrated Management of Acute Malnutrition delivering services through 369 Outpatient Therapeutic Centers and 20 Stabilization centers. And two districts have functional nutrition surveillance system.
